content: The Act may be cited as the "Safe Teen and Novice Driver Uniform Protection Act of 2010" or the "STANDUP Act." Congress finds that motor vehicle crashes are the leading cause of death for Americans aged 15-20, with a high fatality rate for drivers in this age group compared to older drivers. Teenage drivers between 15 and 20 years old are involved in motor vehicle crashes resulting in an average of 167 deaths per week. Drivers aged 16-20 have a fatality rate 4 times higher than those aged 25-70, while 16-year-old drivers have a crash rate almost 10 times higher than those aged 30-60. According to the American Automobile Association. Teenage drivers aged 16 have a crash rate almost 10 times higher than drivers aged 30-60. Teenage drivers comprise slightly more than 1/3 of all fatalities in crashes they are involved in, with nearly 2/3 of fatalities being other drivers, passengers, and pedestrians. According to the American Automobile Association, teenage drivers account for over 1/3 of all fatalities in crashes they are involved in, with nearly 2/3 of fatalities being other individuals. The Insurance Institute for Highway Safety states that the risk of a crash for 16- or 17-year-old drivers doubles with 2 peers in the vehicle and quadruples with 3 or more peers. According to the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration, cognitive distraction from cell phones significantly affects teenage drivers aged 15-20. According to the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration, cognitive distraction from cell phones significantly affects teenage drivers aged 15-20, with more than 50% of motor vehicle crash fatalities involving teenage drivers occurring at night. The Insurance Institute for Highway Safety reported a decrease in fatal and injurious incidents in 1997, the first year of Florida's graduated driver licensing system. According to the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration, more than 50% of motor vehicle crash fatalities involving teenage drivers occur at night. The Insurance Institute for Highway Safety reported a decrease in fatal and injurious incidents among teenage drivers aged 15-18 in 1997, the first year of Florida's graduated driver licensing system. Additionally, the Journal of the American Medical Association found that crashes involving 16-year-old drivers decreased by 25% in Michigan and 27% in North Carolina between 1995 and 1999. Between 1998 and 2000, California's graduated driver licensing program saw a decrease in teenage passenger deaths and injuries. This was part of a trend where crashes involving 16-year-old drivers decreased by 25% in Michigan and 27% in North Carolina between 1995 and 1999. In 1997, North Carolina implemented a comprehensive graduated driver licensing system. According to the Automobile Club of Southern California, California's graduated driver licensing program led to a 40% decrease in teenage passenger deaths and injuries involving 16-year-old drivers between 1998 and 2000. Additionally, the number of at-fault collisions in California involving 16-year-old drivers decreased by 24%. The National Transportation Safety Board also reported positive outcomes from these programs. The National Transportation Safety Board reports that many states have implemented 3-stage graduated driver licensing systems, but some have not yet implemented other basic safety features to protect teenage and novice drivers. Many states have implemented 3-stage graduated driver licensing systems, but some have not yet added other basic safety features to protect teenage and novice drivers. A 2001 Harris Poll shows strong support for requirements such as 30 to 50 hours of practice driving with an adult and a 6-month learner's permit period. A 2001 Harris Poll reveals strong public support for laws protecting teenage and novice drivers, including requirements for practice driving hours, a learner's permit period, and limits on teenage passengers and supervised driving during high-risk periods. State graduated driver licensing laws are supported by the public, including requirements for practice driving hours, a learner's permit period, and limits on teenage passengers and supervised driving during high-risk periods. A State is compliant with graduated driver licensing laws if novice drivers under 21 follow a 2-stage process before getting an unrestricted license, starting with a learner's permit at 16 years old or older. The 2-stage licensing process for novice drivers includes a learner's permit stage starting at 16 years old, lasting at least 6 months, with restrictions on cellphone use and night driving. The learner's permit stage for novice drivers starts at 16 years old, lasts at least 6 months, prohibits cellphone use and night driving, and remains in effect until the intermediate stage or the driver turns 18. The intermediate stage follows the learner's permit stage, lasting at least 6 months and prohibiting cellphone use for drivers until they reach 18 years of age. The intermediate stage of driving follows the learner's permit stage, lasting at least 6 months. During this stage, drivers are prohibited from using a cellphone or any communications device in nonemergency situations, driving at night, and having more than one non-familial passenger under 21 years of age unless accompanied by a licensed driver over 21 years old. During the intermediate stage of driving, restrictions include no cellphone use, driving at night, and limited passengers under 21 without a licensed driver over 21 present. Additional requirements may be imposed by the Secretary of Transportation. During the learner's permit stage, requirements include 40 hours of behind-the-wheel training with a licensed driver over 21, a driver training course, and other potential Secretary of Transportation requirements. The permit is valid until the driver turns 18. During the learner's permit stage, transportation requirements may include at least 40 hours of behind-the-wheel training with a licensed driver over 21, a driver training course, and supervision by a licensed driver over 21 at all times. During the learner's permit or intermediate stage, a driver must be accompanied by a licensed driver over 21 at all times while operating a motor vehicle. During the learner's permit or intermediate stage, a driver's license may be automatically delayed for individuals convicted of driving-related offenses like driving while intoxicated. During the learner's permit or intermediate stage, a driver's license may be automatically delayed for individuals convicted of driving-related offenses such as driving while intoxicated, misrepresentation of age, reckless driving, driving without a seat belt, speeding, or any other driving-related offense. The Secretary of Transportation will establish regulations for implementing penalties for driving-related offenses, including reckless driving, not wearing a seat belt, speeding, and other offenses. Incentive grants will be provided as part of the regulations established by the Secretary of Transportation for driving-related offenses. The Secretary of Transportation will award grants to States in compliance with section 3(a) for the first 3 fiscal years after the Act's enactment. States must submit an application including a certification by the Governor to be eligible for the grant. Grants awarded under this section can be used for enforcing a 2-stage licensing process and training for law enforcement personnel. Funds from grants awarded under this section can be used for enforcing a 2-stage licensing process, training law enforcement personnel, publishing educational materials related to graduated driver licensing laws, and other administrative activities. Authorization of $25,000,000 annually from the Highway Trust Fund for enforcing 2-stage licensing, training personnel, publishing educational materials, and other administrative activities related to graduated driver licensing laws. SEC. 5. WITHHOLDING OF FUNDS FOR NONCOMPLIANCE. During the fourth fiscal year after the enactment of the Act, the Secretary will withhold 3% of funds from non-compliant states, increasing to 5% in the fifth fiscal year. During the fifth fiscal year after the Act's enactment, the Secretary will withhold 5% of funds from states not compliant with section 3(a) of title 23, United States Code. During the sixth and subsequent fiscal years, the Secretary will withhold 10% of funds from states not compliant with section 3(a) of title 23, United States Code. The Secretary will withhold 10% of funds from states not compliant with section 3(a) of title 23, United States Code after the fifth fiscal year. The withheld funds will be available until the end of the sixth fiscal year. Funds withheld from non-compliant states under section 3(a) of title 23, United States Code will remain available for distribution until the end of the third fiscal year following the fiscal year for which they were appropriated. Funds withheld under subsection (a) will remain available for distribution to the State until the end of the third fiscal year following the fiscal year for which they were appropriated. Any amount withheld after the sixth fiscal year may not be distributed to the State. Funds withheld under subsection (a) will be available for distribution to the State until the end of the third fiscal year following the fiscal year for which they were appropriated. If the State complies with section 3(a) before the funds expire, the Secretary of Transportation will distribute the withheld amounts to the State. Upon compliance with section 3(a), the Secretary of Transportation will distribute any withheld funds to the State. The distributed amount will be available for expenditure by the State until the end of the third fiscal year following the year of apportionment. Any funds distributed to the State must be spent within three fiscal years, or they will be returned to the Treasury if not used. Noncompliance with section 3(a) will result in withheld funds reverting back to the Treasury. Any unspent funds distributed to the State must be used within three fiscal years, or they will revert back to the Treasury. Noncompliance with section 3(a) will result in withheld funds also reverting back to the Treasury.
